title: UK's oldest prisoner, 104, is retired lorry driver jailed for child sex attacks
text:

The oldest prisoner in a UK jail has been revealed as a paedophile who is aged 104.

Ralph Clarke was sentenced to a 13-year term for historic child sex attacks in 2016 at the age of 101.

The retired lorry driver turned 104 this year as new research shows our jails are full of pensioners.

He is one of 13,617 aged over 50 out of a prison population of 82,710 as of June 2019, a figure which has tripled since 2002.

Of those,1,759 were 70 or older.

(Image: PA)

The rise in OAPs behind bars has led to a call for prisons to be specifically designed to deal with their care demands.

The Prison Officers Association warned their members are dealing with inmates who are "dying in front of them."

Many are frail, incontinent or have dementia, according to the POA.

"Young staff trained to be prison officers are becoming carers," said one officer with 30 years' experience.

(Image: X80001)

"Older prisoners are starting big sentences. Young prison officers are coming straight from university, with very little life experience.

"They have to deal with major traumatic events like somebody dying in front of them."

Tougher prison sentences and historic sex cases are partly to blame.

Dr Mary Turner, reader in health services research at Huddersfield University, told the BBC: "People tend to get longer sentences, even in older age, than they might have done in the past.

"There are more older people going into prison than there are being released."

(Image: Birmingham Mail)

Secure care homes, and alternatives to prison may be part of the solution.

Inspector of Prison Peter Clarke warned the number of men over 50 being held would rise to 14,000 by 2022, around 17 percent of the prison population.

"When prisoners get older, less capable physically or infirm, they don't provide an escape risk," he said.

"They still have to be held in custody very often and it's not to say they wouldn't present a risk to the public if they were completely at liberty.

"The question is do they need to be held in levels of security which are not needed for their physical capabilities and which inevitably are very expensive as well?"



The Prison Service is working closely with local councils and healthcare providers to make sure the needs of elderly prisoners are being met.

“Last year, a Chief Inspector of Prisons report found there was good work to adapt prisons for older inmates. We updated guidance for governors," said a spokesman.



Local authorities are responsible for assessing and meeting eligible social care and support needs of adult prisoners detained in their area.
